    <article class="markdown-body entry-content" itemprop="text"><h1><a id="user-content-practical-machine-learning-course-project" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#practical-machine-learning-course-project"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Practical Machine Learning: Course project</h1>
<pre lang="{r"><code>library(knitr)
opts_chunk$set(cache=TRUE)
set.seed(1)
</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-the-goal-of-the-project" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#the-goal-of-the-project"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>The goal of the project</h2>
<p>The description of the assignment contains the following information on the dataset:</p>
<blockquote>
<p>In this project, your goal will be to use data from accelerometers on the belt, forearm, arm, and dumbell of 6 participants. They were asked to perform barbell lifts correctly and incorrectly in 5 different ways.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>The goal is</p>
<blockquote>
<p>to predict the manner in which they did the exercise.</p>
</blockquote>
<h2><a id="user-content-the-training-of-the-model" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#the-training-of-the-model"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>The training of the model</h2>
<p>In the following, I describe the steps concerning the training of a predictive model.</p>
<h3><a id="user-content-read-the-data" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#read-the-data"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Read the data</h3>
<p>First, the <code>.csv</code> file contain the training data is read into R. Here, unavailable values are set as <code>NA</code>.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>rawData &lt;- read.csv("pml-training.csv", na.strings = c("NA", ""))
</code></pre>
<h3><a id="user-content-reduce-the-dataset" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#reduce-the-dataset"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Reduce the dataset</h3>
<p>In the next step, I check the proportion of missing values (<code>NA</code>s) in the columns.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>propNAs &lt;- colMeans(is.na(rawData))
table(propNAs)
</code></pre>
<p>There are <code>r sum(as.logical(propNAs))</code> columns in which almost all values (<code>r paste0(round(max(propNAs) * 100, 2), "%")</code>) are missing. If a column contains a large number of <code>NA</code>s, it will not be of great use for training the model. Hence, these columns will be removed. Only the columns without any <code>NA</code>s will be kept.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code># index of columns with NA values
idx &lt;- !propNAs
# check
sum(idx)
# remove these columns  
rawDataReduced &lt;- rawData[idx]
# check
ncol(rawDataReduced)
</code></pre>
<p>There are further unnecessary columns that can be removed. The column <code>X</code> contains the row numbers. The column <code>user_name</code> contains the name of the user. Of course, these variables cannot predictors for the type of exercise.</p>
<p>Furthermore, the three columns containing time stamps (<code>raw_timestamp_part_1</code>, <code>raw_timestamp_part_2</code>, and <code>cvtd_timestamp</code>) will not be used.</p>
<p>The factors <code>new_window</code> and <code>num_window</code> are not related to sensor data. They will be removed too.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code># find columns not containing sensor measurement data
idx &lt;- grep("^X$|user_name|timestamp|window", names(rawDataReduced))
# check
length(idx)
# remove columns
rawDataReduced2 &lt;- rawDataReduced[-idx]
</code></pre>
<h3><a id="user-content-preparing-the-data-for-training" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#preparing-the-data-for-training"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Preparing the data for training</h3>
<p>Now, the dataset contains one outcome column (<code>classe</code>) and <code>r ncol(rawDataReduced) - 1L</code> feature columns. The function <code>createDataPartition</code> of the <code>caret</code> package is used to split the data into a training and a cross-validation data set. Here, 70% of the data goes into the training set.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>library(caret)
</code></pre>
<pre lang="{r"><code>inTrain &lt;- createDataPartition(y = rawDataReduced2$classe, p = 0.7, list = FALSE)
</code></pre>
<p>The index <code>inTrain</code> is used to split the data.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>training &lt;- rawDataReduced2[inTrain, ]
# the number of columns on the training set
nrow(training)
crossval &lt;- rawDataReduced2[-inTrain, ]
# the number of rows in the cross-validation set
nrow(crossval)
</code></pre>
<h3><a id="user-content-train-a-model" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#train-a-model"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Train a model</h3>
<p>I used the <em>random-forest</em> technique to generate a predictive model. In sum, 10 models were trained. I played around with the parameters passed to <code>trControl</code> and specified different models with bootstrapping (<code>method = "boot"</code>) and cross-validation (<code>method = "cv"</code>).</p>
<p>It took more than one day to train all models. Afterwards I tested their performance on the cross-validation dataset. It turned out that all models showed a good performance (because their accuracy was above 99%) though their training times were quite different.</p>
<p>Due to the similar performance, I will present the model with the shortest training time.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>library(randomForest)
</code></pre>
<pre lang="{r"><code>trControl &lt;- trainControl(method = "cv", number = 2)
modFit &lt;- train(classe ~ ., data = training, method = "rf", prox = TRUE, trControl = trControl)
</code></pre>
<h3><a id="user-content-evaluate-the-model-out-of-sample-error" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#evaluate-the-model-out-of-sample-error"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Evaluate the model (out-of-sample error)</h3>
<p>First, the final model is used to predict the outcome in the cross-validation dataset.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>pred &lt;- predict(modFit, newdata = crossval)
</code></pre>
<p>Second, the function <code>confusionMatrix</code> is used to calculate the accuracy of the prediction.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>coMa &lt;- confusionMatrix(pred, reference = crossval$classe)
acc &lt;- coMa$overall["Accuracy"]
acc
</code></pre>
<p>The accuracy of the prediction is <code>r paste0(round(acc * 100, 2), "%")</code>. Hence, the <em>out-of-sample error</em> is <code>r paste0(round(100 - acc * 100, 2), "%")</code>.</p>
<h3><a id="user-content-variable-importance" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#variable-importance"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Variable importance</h3>
<p>The five most important variables in the model and their relative importance values are:</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>vi &lt;- varImp(modFit)$importance
vi[head(order(unlist(vi), decreasing = TRUE), 5L), , drop = FALSE]
</code></pre>
<hr>
<h4><a id="user-content-the-source-of-the-data" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#the-source-of-the-data"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>The source of the data</h4>
<p>The assignment is based on data of weight lifting exercises. It has been published:</p>
<p>Velloso, E.; Bulling, A.; Gellersen, H.; Ugulino, W.; Fuks, H. <a href="http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har#ixzz34irPKNuZ" rel="nofollow">Qualitative Activity Recognition of Weight Lifting Exercises</a>. <em>Proceedings of 4th International Conference in Cooperation with SIGCHI (Augmented Human '13)</em>. Stuttgart, Germany: ACM SIGCHI, 2013.</p>
</article>
